oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Graduates of Columbia NYA Beauty Culture School, from the Nashville Times, 1940 March 01
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A captioned photo from the Nashville Times (1940), about graduates in the beauty culture school in Columbia, Tennessee. The caption reads: “Columbia, Tenn., March 1 (Spl.) Students of the NYA girls school here, which reopened at the historic Columbia Institute buildings in January of 1939, are looking forward with interest to Saturday. It is on that day the first class of this school to graduate in beauty culture, which is a major subject, will got to Nashville to take the state examinations before the State Board of Cosmotology Saturday. In the NYA school there are 102 girls, from all parts of the state. Back row, left to right, Kathryn Hulin, Coley Wright, Thelma Kirk, Mable Wilson, Dora Alsup, Hettie Noles, Irene Esson, Viola Williams, Hazle Crabtree, Jewell Robison, Fairisee Weatherington. Front row, left to right, Mary Ellen Raulston, Era Scott, Elizabeth Puckett, Marjorie Burkheart, Miss Dezzie Eason (teacher) Pauline McDonald, Lorene Bradford, Nina Lou Gray and Mable Knight.” National Youth Administration (NYA) was established by executive order on 26 June 1935 as a division of the Works Progress Administration. The student work program eventually helped more than 2 million students find jobs. The agency was almost completely decentralized, with many of the projects being administered by states and communities. Forms part of the Nashville Times newspaper collection. 1 digital photo.
